posts.name: Travis Hoffman
posts.cooked:
I know Vivid Hosting will be updating wiring examples, but in the meantime, presuming I add 18 AWG power leads to the radio to satisfy R626-C , I’d like to discern whether the attached diagram is legal per Team Update 8 .  I think I and others seeking to pursue similar would love some assistance from those who can authoritatively comment.

The below is what I’d LIKE to do given the original feature set advertised for this radio.

My ideal setup:

For #1 , the passive REV injector, wired correctly and utilizing a standard Ethernet cable to complete the hookup, would take the place of the blue RoboRIO-to-Radio RIO port cable at the top of the attached diagram.

Are we good here, or are we somehow still cooking the RoboRIO ethernet port with this setup?

Also, I believe this setup satisfies R626-A, but I am not sure, because R626 is unclear here.  I PRESUME it is telling me that both AUX1 and AUX2 are still available for POE use, and EACH of those ports must only have a single POE device attached to it, and EACH of those ports is subject to an independent up to 2A @ 12 VDC current draw.  But it could be something else entirely - R626-A needs to be rewritten for crystal clarity.

Who might authoritatively clarify R626(-A) so we all know, without a doubt, what POE connectivity is still permitted?

Thanks in advance.

image 791×598 75.2 KB

image 791×598 75.2 KB

image 791×598 75.2 KB

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
Travis_Hoffman:

Are we good here, or are we somehow still cooking the RoboRIO ethernet port with this setup?

You’re good here. Having the POE injector here is enough to stop the issue.

Note, this is only in response to the cooking the port. Not to the legality of powering 2 POE devices. That I agree is slightly confusing.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: Are we doing away with the RPM ?
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: The RPM is also usable as a POE injector. Assuming you were using an RPM , nothing has changed, other then basically disallowing the AUX POE outputs due to the new R626. But doing that was risky in the past anyway.

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: Thanks for the clarification.  That pic was…confusing…
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: Thats one of the issues of having so many legal ways to power the radio. I fully expect many of the options to be removed for the 2026 season.

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
To be clear…if using the RPM from Rev to power your radio, do NOT wire the 12v Weidmuller connectors on the radio to the PDP , PDH , or any other 12v source.

The 12v input and passive POE are internally connected in the radio and you will end up blowing a fuse or repeatedly tripping a breaker somewhere.

If you want to redundantly power the radio via the 12v input AND passive POE, then use a different POE injector that outputs 12v when wired to the PDH / PDP and directly connecting the PDP / PDH to the 12v radio input.

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Travis Hoffman
posts.cooked:
The pic was taken from https://frc-radio.vivid-hosting.net/overview/wiring-your-radio from the Vivid Hosting website.  The page also covers the use of the RPM and the related caveats.

None of the example pics showed exactly what I intend to do, so I picked one of the ones that was closest and explained the differences.  Just wanted a visual reference.

The Vivid Hosting page is not a substitute for the game manual - make certain you conform to all robot rules when referencing anything I linked.  Standard disclaimer.

posts.name: Max Arnold
posts.cooked: Is it legal and/or safe to wire the VH-109 directly to the PDH with a 10 Amp fuse and run a normal ethernet cable from the RIO port to the roboRIO?

posts.name: Kiet Chau
posts.cooked:
Not quite with the changes to R703. You need to use an ethernet cable with the 2 pairs (blue and brown in TIA568A/B).

So, if you a) use a PoE injector cable/device, b) modify an ethernet cable to inject power over the blue/brown pairs, c) modify an ethernet cable to electrically isolate the blue/brown pairs, d) plug the roboRIO into the AUX ports with the DIP switches turned off/ DS port or e) use an ethernet cable with only two pairs, you’ll be in compliance with the changes for R703.
